private_information: I can only manipulate blocks labeled with vowels: A, E, I.
I may only pick up or place a single top block at a time and only if it is a vowel.
vowel_agent.goal: Cooperate to rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, and L is on the table.

private_information: I can only manipulate blocks labeled with consonants: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L.
I may only pick up or place a single top block at a time and only if it is a consonant.
consonant_agent.goal: Cooperate to rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, and L is on the table.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and must integrate their local knowledge to produce a single PDDL domain and problem targeting the FastDownwards solver.
I must keep the actions of the vowel agent and the consonant agent distinct in the combined domain.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate agent reports and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem that can be solved by FastDownwards to achieve the global stacking goal.

public_information: There are twelve uniquely labelled blocks: A, D, J, L, I, C, E, B, K, G, H, F.
Agents can only interact with blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
Agents may move only one block at a time.
One agent is restricted to manipulating vowel-labelled blocks and the other to consonant-labelled blocks.

Initial stacking configuration: A is on the table, D is on top of A, J is on top of D, B is on top of J, L is on the table, E is on top of L, K is on top of E, H is on top of K, I is on the table, C is on top of I, G is on top of C, F is on top of B.
Goal configuration: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, and L on the table.

report.system_prompt: You are a local agent that can manipulate vowel-labelled blocks. Provide a concise report of which vowel blocks you can access at the top of stacks, what moves involving vowels you can perform given the public initial state, and any local constraints or assumptions that affect vowel moves.
report.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. Using the public information in the environment, list the vowel blocks you can move, indicate which of those are currently top blocks and thus immediately movable, describe any simple one-step moves you could perform, and mention any missing information you need for longer planning. Do not emit PDDL. Provide structured observations and possible local actions.

report.system_prompt: You are a local agent that can manipulate consonant-labelled blocks. Provide a concise report of which consonant blocks you can access at the top of stacks, what moves involving consonants you can perform given the public initial state, and any local constraints or assumptions that affect consonant moves.
report.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. Using the public information in the environment, list the consonant blocks you can move, indicate which of those are currently top blocks and thus immediately movable, describe any simple one-step moves you could perform, and mention any missing information you need for longer planning. Do not emit PDDL. Provide structured observations and possible local actions.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL tailored for the FastDownwards solver. Your task is to integrate the local reports from two agents and produce a single coherent PDDL domain and PDDL problem that encode the block manipulation constraints and the global goal. The combined domain must keep the vowel agent actions distinct from the consonant agent actions. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatibility when choosing requirements and syntax.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Use the environment public information and the private information of both agents, together with the reports they produce, to build a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem that FastDownwards can solve to reach the stated goal. Represent agents actions distinctly, for example using action names move-vowel and move-consonant and keep their preconditions reflecting that each can only move top blocks of their allowed letter set. Include typing or predicates as needed and ensure the initial state encodes the exact stacking configuration and the goal encodes the desired final stack A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on the table. Think step by step and resolve any naming ambiguities from reports. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
